content: On p. 19 of _Logic and Mechanized Reasoning_, one finds the notation <|. An example given is map (fun x => x + 3) <| range 7. But in the code from the LAMR repository, <| is replaced with $. Is there a difference between <| and $? More generally, is there documentation on these two operators? Pointers are much appreciated.
Check the survival guide, it states that it is merely notation.

They are exactly the same. $ was the Lean spelling, which still works in Lean4, but I think <| is now the recommended way to spell it. You can think of it as "enclose everything that follows in parenthesis", e.g f <| a b is the same as f (a b), instead of f a b (which means (f a) b)
Note that now there is also |>, that works on the left.
Kevin Cheung has marked this topic as resolved.
